Laterally flattened and elongate-oval with thick lips, single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail fin. Pectoral fin with lower rays free and extended into fingerâ€“like appendages used to support the fish when resting on the bottom. Body colour plain brown with a large silvery patch on side of head and over gills and row of four silvery spots along lateral line.

Juveniles quite different in appearance being plump and silvery-blue with about 6 black transverse bars across the back.

Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern Mozambique.

Usually found singly on rocky shores and shallow reefs but extends to a depth of 240 m. Juveniles common in rock pools in the Western Cape. Often sits on the bottom using the thickened free lower pectoral rays as support.
Feeds on benthic invertebrates, such as crustaceans and bivalves. Ingests mouthfuls of sand, sifting out prey with the gill-rakers before ejecting the sand though the gill openings.
Matures as a length of 25 cm and spawns in summer. Juveniles initially silvery and acquire adult colouration when about 5 cm in length.

Similar in body shape and habits to the Redfingers Cheilodactylus fasciatus (note the confusingly similar but different genus name), but that species has a quite different colour pattern, being speckled with irregular brown spots and with staggered lateral brown bars. The Bank steenbras Chirodactylus grandis in the same genus also occurs in the region but that species rarely visits shallow waters and is also uniformly pale or dark grey.
